elements.content: Separations of f-block elements are a critical aspect of nuclear waste processing. Redox-based separations offer promise, but challenges remain in stabilizing and differentiating actinides in high oxidation states. The investigation of new ligand types that provide thermodynamic stabilization to high-valent actinides is essential for expanding their fundamental chemistry and to elaborate new separation techniques and storage methods. We report herein the preparation and characterization of Th and U complexes of the pyridyl-hydroxylamine ligand, N-tert-butyl-N-(pyridin-2-yl)­hydroxylamine (pyNO–). Electrochemical studies performed on the homoleptic complexes [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) revealed significant stabilization of the U complex upon one-electron oxidation. The salt [U­(pyNO)4]+ was isolated by chemical oxidation of [U­(pyNO)4]; spectroscopic and computational data support assignment as a UV cation.
elements.clean_text: Separations of f-block elements are a critical aspect of nuclear waste processing. Redox-based separations offer promise, but challenges remain in stabilizing and differentiating actinides in high oxidation states. The investigation of new ligand types that provide thermodynamic stabilization to high-valent actinides is essential for expanding their fundamental chemistry and to elaborate new separation techniques and storage methods. We report herein the preparation and characterization of Th and U complexes of the pyridyl-hydroxylamine ligand, N-tert-butyl-N-(pyridin-2-yl)hydroxylamine (pyNO-). Electrochemical studies performed on the homoleptic complexes [M(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) revealed significant stabilization of the U complex upon one-electron oxidation. The salt [U(pyNO)4]+ was isolated by chemical oxidation of [U(pyNO)4]; spectroscopic and computational data support assignment as a UV cation.

elements.content: A pyridyl-hydroxylamine ligand is applied to the coordination chemistry of thorium and uranium. Solution electrochemical measurements of the resulting complexes indicate a strong stabilization of the higher oxidation states, observations that are supported by electronic structure calculations with DFT.
elements.clean_text: A pyridyl-hydroxylamine ligand is applied to the coordination chemistry of thorium and uranium. Solution electrochemical measurements of the resulting complexes indicate a strong stabilization of the higher oxidation states, observations that are supported by electronic structure calculations with DFT.

elements.content: A significant challenge to the use of nuclear power is the generation of high-level liquid waste (HLLW) which presents severe radiological health risks and storage challenges. Understanding and control of metal oxidation states is crucial to develop and optimize new separations chemistries and to assess and confer long-term stability to waste forms of HLLW. For example, the Plutonium Uranium Redox EXtraction (PUREX) process, which is used to reprocess nuclear fuel, makes use of differences in redox chemistry for the separation of Pu and U from lanthanides and heavier actinides and for the separation of Pu and U from one another. The PUREX process can also incorporate separation of Np from U by selectively reducing the neptunyl ion (NpVIO2 2+) to NpVO2 +. Similarly, in the SESAME process, Am in the post-PUREX waste stream is oxidized to AmIV, which facilitates its separation from CmIII. We, and others, have engaged in developing ligands that promote f-element redox chemistry and stabilize higher oxidation states. In all of these contexts, it is important to obtain information on the relative redox thermodynamics for f-block elements and to understand how ligands stabilize different oxidation states. Computational chemistry has begun to show predictive power for redox couples of d- and f-block metal complexes, but calibration with experimental data is essential.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

A significant challenge to the use of nuclear power is the generation of high-level liquid waste (HLLW) which presents severe radiological health risks and storage challenges. Understanding and control of metal oxidation states is crucial to develop and optimize new separations chemistries and to assess and confer long-term stability to waste forms of HLLW. For example, the Plutonium Uranium Redox EXtraction (PUREX) process, which is used to reprocess nuclear fuel, makes use of differences in redox chemistry for the separation of Pu and U from lanthanides and heavier actinides and for the separation of Pu and U from one another. The PUREX process can also incorporate separation of Np from U by selectively reducing the neptunyl ion (NpVIO2 2+) to NpVO2 +. Similarly, in the SESAME process, Am in the post-PUREX waste stream is oxidized to AmIV, which facilitates its separation from CmIII. We, and others, have engaged in developing ligands that promote f-element redox chemistry and stabilize higher oxidation states. In all of these contexts, it is important to obtain information on the relative redox thermodynamics for f-block elements and to understand how ligands stabilize different oxidation states. Computational chemistry has begun to show predictive power for redox couples of d- and f-block metal complexes, but calibration with experimental data is essential.

elements.content: Previous reports on the homoleptic complex [Ce­(pyNO)4] (pyNO– = N-tert-butyl-N-(pyridin-2-yl)­hydroxyl­amine) and congeners showed that the pyNO– ligands provided unprecedented stabilization of the CeIV cation, as determined by the potential for electrochemical reduction to CeIII. In an effort to extend the coordination chemistry of the pyNO− ligand framework to 5f block elements, we report herein the synthesis and electrochemisty of [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) () and the preparation and structure of the uranyl complex, [UO2(pyNO)3K] n , obtained through an oxidative group transfer reaction with the pyNO– ligand. The pyNO– ligands significantly stabilized the pentavalent uranium congener [UV(pyNO)4]+, which was also prepared, relative to other reported UV complexes. These results expand our knowledge of the redox chemistry of U and Th with electron donating ligands and establish a basis for the application of the pyNO– framework to the preparation and study of high-valent transuranic elements.
elements.clean_text: Previous reports on the homoleptic complex [Ce(pyNO)4] (pyNO- = N-tert-butyl-N-(pyridin-2-yl)hydroxylamine) and congeners showed that the pyNO- ligands provided unprecedented stabilization of the CeIV cation, as determined by the potential for electrochemical reduction to CeIII. In an effort to extend the coordination chemistry of the pyNO- ligand framework to 5f block elements, we report herein the synthesis and electrochemisty of [M(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) () and the preparation and structure of the uranyl complex, [UO2(pyNO)3K] n , obtained through an oxidative group transfer reaction with the pyNO- ligand. The pyNO- ligands significantly stabilized the pentavalent uranium congener [UV(pyNO)4]+, which was also prepared, relative to other reported UV complexes. These results expand our knowledge of the redox chemistry of U and Th with electron donating ligands and establish a basis for the application of the pyNO- framework to the preparation and study of high-valent transuranic elements.

elements.content: To establish the study of 5f elements with the pyNO– ligands, we first sought to prepare [Th­(pyNO)4]. We expected the ThIV cation would be redox-silent such that [Th­(pyNO)4] would provide baseline expectations for ligand-based redox activity with this framework. The complex [Th­(pyNO)4] was prepared as a bright yellow crystalline solid in 82% yield by salt-metathesis of [ThCl4(DME)2] with 4 equiv of K­(pyNO). The 1H NMR spectrum of [Th­(pyNO)4] featured four aromatic signals and a singlet at δ 1.40 for the tBu protons of four chemically equivalent pyNO– ligands (see ESI). The 13C­{1H} NMR spectrum of the complex revealed the expected 5 aromatic signals and 2 aliphatic signals for the pyNO– ligands. Having established conditions effective for the isolation of [Th­(pyNO)4], we next pursued the isostructural uranium congener. The uranium complex [U­(pyNO)4] was isolated as a red crystalline solid in 46% yield by a protonolysis reaction between [U­(N­(SiMe3))3] and 5 equiv of pyNOH at −35 °C. The mechanism by which pyNOH oxidizes U was not studied; however, we note that increasing the amount of pyNOH in the reaction did not increase the yield of [U­(pyNO)4]. The 1H NMR spectrum of [U­(pyNO)4] revealed five resonances for the equivalent pyNO– ligands, with the chemical shifts and line broadening being consistent with a UIV center.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of Complexes

To establish the study of 5f elements with the pyNO- ligands, we first sought to prepare [Th(pyNO)4]. We expected the ThIV cation would be redox-silent such that [Th(pyNO)4] would provide baseline expectations for ligand-based redox activity with this framework. The complex [Th(pyNO)4] was prepared as a bright yellow crystalline solid in 82% yield by salt-metathesis of [ThCl4(DME)2] with 4 equiv of K(pyNO). The 1H NMR spectrum of [Th(pyNO)4] featured four aromatic signals and a singlet at δ 1.40 for the tBu protons of four chemically equivalent pyNO- ligands (see ESI). The 13C{1H} NMR spectrum of the complex revealed the expected 5 aromatic signals and 2 aliphatic signals for the pyNO- ligands. Having established conditions effective for the isolation of [Th(pyNO)4], we next pursued the isostructural uranium congener. The uranium complex [U(pyNO)4] was isolated as a red crystalline solid in 46% yield by a protonolysis reaction between [U(N(SiMe3))3] and 5 equiv of pyNOH at -35 °C. The mechanism by which pyNOH oxidizes U was not studied; however, we note that increasing the amount of pyNOH in the reaction did not increase the yield of [U(pyNO)4]. The 1H NMR spectrum of [U(pyNO)4] revealed five resonances for the equivalent pyNO- ligands, with the chemical shifts and line broadening being consistent with a UIV center.

elements.content: In the absence of air and moisture [Th­(pyNO)4] was stable indefinitely at room temperature in the solid state and in THF/CH2Cl2 solution. Similarly, [U­(pyNO)4] proved stable in the solid state with samples stored at −35 °C for months remaining unchanged. Solutions of [U­(pyNO)4], however, visibly darkened and became brown (<5 min in chlorinated solvents, ∼30 min in THF) with a multitude of diamagnetic impurities evident by NMR spectroscopy. None of these degradation products were isolated; however, the fact that they are diamagnetic and associated with the isolation of [UO2(pyNO)3K] n (vide infra) suggested O atom abstraction from the pyNO– ligands. As a result of the instability of [U­(pyNO)4], all solution phase measurements on this complex were collected as rapidly as possible.

Similarly, [U(pyNO)4] proved stable in the solid state with samples stored at -35 °C for months remaining unchanged. Solutions of [U(pyNO)4], however, visibly darkened and became brown (<5 min in chlorinated solvents, ~30 min in THF) with a multitude of diamagnetic impurities evident by NMR spectroscopy. None of these degradation products were isolated; however, the fact that they are diamagnetic and associated with the isolation of [UO2(pyNO)3K] n  (vide infra) suggested O atom abstraction from the pyNO- ligands. As a result of the instability of [U(pyNO)4], all solution phase measurements on this complex were collected as rapidly as possible.

elements.content: [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U) complexes all crystallized in the C 2/c space-group with near identical unit cells. The metal coordination environments consisted of four roughly planar pyNO ligands, which bound through the pyridyl and hydroxylamine oxygen donors. The complexes all exhibited distorted trigonal dodecahedron geometries with approximate D 2d symmetry. The metal ions each resided on crystallographic C2 axis, which rendered the two sets of trans pyNO– ligands equivalent. Within the pyNO– ligands there were only slight changes in bond metrics between complexes, consistent with the pyNO– ligands being fully reduced and bound to tetravalent cations. The previously reported Ce complex featured the shortest M–O bonds at 2.2351(12) and 2.2361(12) Å, followed by U, 2.250(2) Å, and Th, 2.3013(12) and 2.981(12) Å, reflecting the increasing ionic radii of the metal ions (Ce, U, Th = 0.97, 1.00, 1.05 Å for 8 coordinate complexes). Notably, attempts to prepare [U­(pyNO)4] from UCl4 and excess K­(pyNO) instead gave the uranyl complex [UO2(pyNO)3K] n () as an orange crystalline solid in 62% yield (). Oxidation of UIV, MoV, VIII by O atom abstraction from hydroxamic acids was previously documented; therefore, [UO2(pyNO)3K] n likely arose from oxygen atom abstraction from pyNO– by the oxophilic uranium cation. Formation of uranyl (UVIO2 2+) specie(s) likely accounts for the observed instability of [U­(pyNO)4] in solution. X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies performed on [UO2(pyNO)3K] n revealed a polymeric structure with each [UO2(pyNO)3]− unit bridged by a K cation; a truncated depiction of the polymeric structure is shown in .

elements.content: The coordination modes of the pyNO– ligands in [UO2(pyNO)3K] n differed significantly compared to those observed for [U­(pyNO)4]. For [UO2(pyNO)3K] n , one pyNO– ligand bound the uranium cation through the pyridyl donor and hydroxylamine O(1) atom, as in [U­(pyNO)4]. However, the other two pyNO– groups coordinated in an η2 fashion through the hydroxylamine N and O atoms (N(4), N(6), O(2), and O(3)), with the pyridyl donors bound to K+ cations. The UO bond lengths of 1.803(3) and 1.806(3) Å are typical for uranyl complexes. As expected, the UO2 fragment is near linear (∠OUO = 177.6(1)°); the slight deviation is possibly a result of a short O–K+ contact (2.803 Å). [UO2(pyNO)3K] n was insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF and CH2Cl2 as well as strong donor solvents such as pyridine, consistent with the polymeric structure being resistant to dissociation.

However, the other two pyNO- groups coordinated in an η2 fashion through the hydroxylamine N and O atoms (N(4), N(6), O(2), and O(3)), with the pyridyl donors bound to K+ cations. The UO bond lengths of 1.803(3) and 1.806(3) Å are typical for uranyl complexes. As expected, the UO2 fragment is near linear (∠OUO = 177.6(1)°); the slight deviation is possibly a result of a short O-K+ contact (2.803 Å). [UO2(pyNO)3K] n  was insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF and CH2Cl2 as well as strong donor solvents such as pyridine, consistent with the polymeric structure being resistant to dissociation.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded for the [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) complexes and are presented in . For comparison, the CV for [Ce­(pyNO)4], which has been reported previously, was measured under the same conditions and is also included here. Sweeps to negative potential in the CV of [Ce­(pyNO)4] revealed the CeIII/IV couple at E 1/2 = −1.82 V versus Fc/Fc+. Cathodic scans showed poorly reversible, ligand-centered oxidation processes with major waves at E c = −0.45 and +0.62 V. The CV for [Th­(pyNO)4] was similar to that for [Ce­(pyNO)4], with poorly reversible ligand-centered oxidation processes observed at E c –0.57 and +0.51 V. As expected, reduction of [Th­(pyNO)4] did not occur within the solvent discharge limits, reflecting the highly reducing nature of ThIII. Likewise, reduction of UIV to UIII was not observed in CVs of [U­(pyNO)4]. Cathodic sweeps for [U­(pyNO)4] revealed a wave at E c = −0.89 V, which was shifted by roughly −0.4 V relative to the first ligand-centered oxidation wave for [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th). The process was also essentially reversible on the CV time scale as shown by scan rate dependence experiments (see Figure S11). These differences in electrochemistry lead us to attribute the first oxidation event for [U­(pyNO)4] as metal-centered, giving [UV(pyNO)4]+. While a range of potentials for the UIV/V couple have been reported, for neutral complexes with no U-ligand multiple bonding, E 1/2 values of > –0.8 V are typical; e.g., E 1/2 (UIV/V) = −0.48 V for [(C5Me5)2U­(−NCPh2)]. Thus, analogous to [Ce­(pyNO)4], the pyNO– ligands evidently provide significant stabilization of the higher UV oxidation state. To confirm uranium, rather than pyNO, -centered oxidation, [U­(pyNO)4]+ was prepared in 79% yield by addition of 1 equiv of [Fc]­[BArF 4] to [U­(pyNO)4]. XRD analysis revealed the complex cation to be structurally analogous to [U­(pyNO)4] (see Figure S8). The N–O distances within the pyNO ligands were similar and averaged ∼1.39 Å (c.f. 1.38 Å for [U­(pyNO)4]); that is, no diagnostic contraction of the N–O bonds was observed which would indicate localized, ligand-centered oxidation. The near-infrared (NIR) spectrum of [U­(pyNO)4]­[BArF 4] shows a sharp but weak (εmax = 59 M–1 cm–1) band at 1601 nm (Figure S7). Peaks of similar energy and intensity were observed for [(C5Me5)2UV(N–Ar)­(X)] complexes and attributed to a characteristic f–f transition. This result suggested that for [U­(pyNO)4]­[BArF 4], U was indeed in the +5 oxidation state; this hypothesis was probed further by DFT studies (vide infra).
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were recorded for the [M(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) complexes and are presented in . For comparison, the CV for [Ce(pyNO)4], which has been reported previously, was measured under the same conditions and is also included here. Sweeps to negative potential in the CV of [Ce(pyNO)4] revealed the CeIII/IV couple at E 1/2 = -1.82 V versus Fc/Fc+. Cathodic scans showed poorly reversible, ligand-centered oxidation processes with major waves at E c = -0.45 and +0.62 V. The CV for [Th(pyNO)4] was similar to that for [Ce(pyNO)4], with poorly reversible ligand-centered oxidation processes observed at E c -0.57 and +0.51 V. As expected, reduction of [Th(pyNO)4] did not occur within the solvent discharge limits, reflecting the highly reducing nature of ThIII. Likewise, reduction of UIV to UIII was not observed in CVs of [U(pyNO)4]. Cathodic sweeps for [U(pyNO)4] revealed a wave at E c = -0.89 V, which was shifted by roughly -0.4 V relative to the first ligand-centered oxidation wave for [M(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th). The process was also essentially reversible on the CV time scale as shown by scan rate dependence experiments (see Figure S11). These differences in electrochemistry lead us to attribute the first oxidation event for [U(pyNO)4] as metal-centered, giving [UV(pyNO)4]+. While a range of potentials for the UIV/V couple have been reported, for neutral complexes with no U-ligand multiple bonding, E 1/2 values of >-0.8 V are typical; e.g., E  1/2 (UIV/V) = -0.48 V for [(C5Me5)2U(-NCPh2)]. Thus, analogous to [Ce(pyNO)4], the pyNO- ligands evidently provide significant stabilization of the higher UV oxidation state. To confirm uranium, rather than pyNO, -centered oxidation, [U(pyNO)4]+ was prepared in 79% yield by addition of 1 equiv of [Fc][BArF 4] to [U(pyNO)4]. XRD analysis revealed the complex cation to be structurally analogous to [U(pyNO)4] (see Figure S8). The N-O distances within the pyNO ligands were similar and averaged ~1.39 Å (c.f. 1.38 Å for [U(pyNO)4]); that is, no diagnostic contraction of the N-O bonds was observed which would indicate localized, ligand-centered oxidation. The near-infrared (NIR) spectrum of [U(pyNO)4][BArF 4] shows a sharp but weak (εmax = 59 M-1 cm-1) band at 1601 nm (Figure S7). Peaks of similar energy and intensity were observed for [(C5Me5)2UV(N-Ar)(X)] complexes and attributed to a characteristic f-f transition. This result suggested that for [U(pyNO)4][BArF 4], U was indeed in the +5 oxidation state; this hypothesis was probed further by DFT studies (vide infra).

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to gain insight into the electronic structures of [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U) and their oxidation and reduction products. The computed average bond distances of [M­(pyNO)4] and [U­(pyNO)4]+ as well as the experimental crystal structure data are summarized in . The computed structural metrics were in reasonable agreement with XRD data, with M–O and M–N bond distances within 1 and 4% of experiment, respectively, lending validity to the theoretical modeling.
elements.clean_text:
Computation and Electronic Structure

Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out to gain insight into the electronic structures of [M(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U) and their oxidation and reduction products. The computed average bond distances of [M(pyNO)4] and [U(pyNO)4]+ as well as the experimental crystal structure data are summarized in . The computed structural metrics were in reasonable agreement with XRD data, with M-O and M-N bond distances within 1 and 4% of experiment, respectively, lending validity to the theoretical modeling.

elements.content: The calculated and formal spin densities on the metal ions for [M­(pyNO)4]−/0/+ are shown in , where the formal charge on the pyNO ligand was assumed to be −1. For [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U), all three metal ions were unambiguously calculated as being in the +4 oxidation state. Upon one-electron reduction, for [M­(pyNO)4]− (M = Ce, U) only slight deviations between calculated spin densities and formal ones were observed, indicating metal-centered reduction to the +3 metal oxidation state. In contrast, [Th­(pyNO)4]− shows negligible spin density on Th, indicating pyNO–centered reduction. This confirms general chemical expectations given the well-known high stability of the ThIV ion. For the one-electron oxidation product [U­(pyNO)4]+, the spin density of 1.22 on U agreed well with the formal one, indicative of a UV center, consistent with the electrochemical, solid state, and spectroscopic data obtained for [U­(pyNO)4]­[BArF 4] (vide supra).
elements.clean_text: The calculated and formal spin densities on the metal ions for [M(pyNO)4]-/0/+ are shown in , where the formal charge on the pyNO ligand was assumed to be -1. For [M(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U), all three metal ions were unambiguously calculated as being in the +4 oxidation state. Upon one-electron reduction, for [M(pyNO)4]- (M = Ce, U) only slight deviations between calculated spin densities and formal ones were observed, indicating metal-centered reduction to the +3 metal oxidation state. In contrast, [Th(pyNO)4]- shows negligible spin density on Th, indicating pyNO-centered reduction. This confirms general chemical expectations given the well-known high stability of the ThIV ion. For the one-electron oxidation product [U(pyNO)4]+, the spin density of 1.22 on U agreed well with the formal one, indicative of a UV center, consistent with the electrochemical, solid state, and spectroscopic data obtained for [U(pyNO)4][BArF 4] (vide supra).

Selected calculated redox couples are shown in with the absolute redox potentials of the redox couples in Table S3. The predicted potentials for the CeIII/IV and UIV/V couples are −2.08 and −0.98 eV, respectively, in agreement with the experimental values of −1.82 and −1.00 V. The differences of ≤0.26 V were within typical errors for the methods applied and may be attributed in part to insufficient consideration of solvation effects, neglect of multiplet effects of the fn complexes, and lack of counterions. One-electron reduction potentials for [M­(pyNO)4] (M = U, Th) were predicted as −3.79 and −4.10 V, respectively. These values are well outside the electrochemical discharge limits of THF, consistent with the absence of any reduction processes in the CVs of these complexes ().

The frontier molecular orbital energy level diagram for [M­(pyNO)4]− (M = Ce, Th, U) is displayed in . For the CeIII complex, [Ce­(pyNO)4]−, the singly occupied molecular orbital (SOMO) was calculated as localized entirely on Ce and was of 4fδ character. For U­(pyNO)4]−, calculations revealed three unpaired 5f electrons of 5fπ, 5fσ, and 5fϕ character. The electron density was located exclusively on U for the SOMO and SOMO+1, while for the SOMO+2, slight metal-to-ligand backbonding interactions resulted in a small spin density distribution on the pyNO− ligands. This resulted in the slightly lower than expected spin density value of 2.73 (see ). In contrast to [M­(pyNO)4]− (M = Ce, U), the SOMO for [Th­(pyNO)4]− was distributed predominantly on the pyridine rings of the pyNO− ligands, which resulted in appreciable shortening of the Th–O and Th–N bond distances (see Table S1).

elements.content: We have prepared the homoleptic complexes [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) of the hydroxylamine pyNO– ligand and characterized these compounds by standard spectroscopic techniques. The uranyl complex [UO2(pyNO)3K] n was isolated from the reaction of UCl4 with K­(pyNO). Electrochemical measurements performed on [U­(pyNO)4] revealed a high degree of stabilization upon one-electron oxidation. The salt [U­(pyNO)4]­[BArF 4] was subsequently prepared; XRD and NIR measurements suggested a UV center. Computational data further supported this assignment. These results emphasize the utility of the pyNO ligand in stabilizing high-valent metal ions. We expect that these results will find utility in redox-based separations of f-block elements.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have prepared the homoleptic complexes [M(pyNO)4] (M = Th, U) of the hydroxylamine pyNO- ligand and characterized these compounds by standard spectroscopic techniques. The uranyl complex [UO2(pyNO)3K] n  was isolated from the reaction of UCl4 with K(pyNO). Electrochemical measurements performed on [U(pyNO)4] revealed a high degree of stabilization upon one-electron oxidation. The salt [U(pyNO)4][BArF 4] was subsequently prepared; XRD and NIR measurements suggested a UV center. Computational data further supported this assignment. These results emphasize the utility of the pyNO ligand in stabilizing high-valent metal ions. We expect that these results will find utility in redox-based separations of f-block elements.

elements.content: All manipulations were carried out in an N2 atmosphere glovebox. Glassware was oven-dried for at least 3h at 150 °C prior to use. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance 300 and 500 MHz spectrometers. 1H and 13C chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to tetramethylsilane using residual solvent as an internal standard. Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Methods

All manipulations were carried out in an N2 atmosphere glovebox. Glassware was oven-dried for at least 3h at 150 °C prior to use. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance 300 and 500 MHz spectrometers. 1H and 13C chemical shifts are reported in ppm relative to tetramethylsilane using residual solvent as an internal standard. Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 analyzer.

elements.content: Caution! Natural thorium (primary isotope 232 Th) is a weak α-emitter (4.012 MeV) with a half-life of 1.41 × 10 10 years and depleted uranium (primary isotope 238 U) is a weak α-emitter (4.197 MeV) with a half-life of 4.47 × 10 9 years; manipulations and reactions should be carried out in monitored fume hoods or in an inert atmosphere drybox in a radiation laboratory equipped with counting equipment.

elements.content: Solvents were sparged for 20 min with argon and dried using a commercial two-column solvent purification system comprising of columns packed with Q5 reactant (neutral alumina for hexanes) and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. Deuterated solvents were purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories Inc., degassed, and dried over activated 4 Å molecular sieves for at least 24 h prior to use. All reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification unless otherwise noted. [ThCl4(DME)2], [U­(N­(SiMe3)2)3], UCl4, pyNOH, and K­(pyNO), were synthesized according to literature procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Materials

Solvents were sparged for 20 min with argon and dried using a commercial two-column solvent purification system comprising of columns packed with Q5 reactant (neutral alumina for hexanes) and stored over 4 Å molecular sieves. Deuterated solvents were purchased from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories Inc., degassed, and dried over activated 4 Å molecular sieves for at least 24 h prior to use. All reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification unless otherwise noted. [ThCl4(DME)2], [U(N(SiMe3)2)3], UCl4, pyNOH, and K(pyNO), were synthesized according to literature procedures.

elements.content: Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed using a CH-Instruments 620D potentiostat. Cell resistances were all <500 Ω and an internal-resistance correction was applied prior to each measurement. The electrochemical cell consisted of a glassy carbon working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a Ag wire coated with AgCl as a pseudoreference electrode. All potentials are referenced vs the Fc0/+ couple measured as an internal standard.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry

Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed using a CH-Instruments 620D potentiostat. Cell resistances were all <500 Ω and an internal-resistance correction was applied prior to each measurement. The electrochemical cell consisted of a glassy carbon working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a Ag wire coated with AgCl as a pseudoreference electrode. All potentials are referenced vs the Fc0/+ couple measured as an internal standard.

elements.content: X-ray intensity data were collected on a Bruker APEXII CCD area detector or a Bruker APEXIII D8QUEST CMOS area detector, both employing graphite-monochromated Mo-K α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 100(1) K. Rotation frames were integrated using SAINT, producing a listing of unaveraged F 2 and σ­(F 2) values which were then passed to the SHELXT program package for further processing and structure solution. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and for absorption using SADABS or TWINABS. Refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All of the reflections were used during refinement. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were refined using a riding model.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

X-ray intensity data were collected on a Bruker APEXII CCD area detector or a Bruker APEXIII D8QUEST CMOS area detector, both employing graphite-monochromated Mo-K α radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 100(1) K. Rotation frames were integrated using SAINT, producing a listing of unaveraged F 2 and σ(F 2) values which were then passed to the SHELXT program package for further processing and structure solution. The intensity data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and for absorption using SADABS or TWINABS. Refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares based on F 2 using SHELXL-2014. All of the reflections were used during refinement. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and hydrogen atoms were refined using a riding model.

elements.content: Ground-state electronic structure calculations were performed on the [M­(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U) and their oxidation and reduction products as well as Fc0 and Fc+ compounds using the hybrid functional B3LYP implemented in the Gaussian 09. All the geometries were optimized in the gas phase. Harmonic frequency calculations were performed to obtain the corresponding thermochemical corrections and to confirm that the optimized structures were stationary points on the potential energy surface. For each molecule, a subsequent single point using the implicit CPCM solvation model 51 with the Universal Force Field (UFF) radii and Solvent Excluding Surface (SES) was calculated to account for the solvation effects. A relative permittivity of 7.4257 was assumed in the solvation calculations to simulate THF as the solvent experimentally used for all the cases. We applied the 6-311G* basis sets for nonmetal atoms, Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP28MWB and the corresponding ECP28MWB-SEG basis for Ce atom, and Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP60MWB and the corresponding ECP60MWB-SEG basis for actinide atoms Th and U, and Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP10MDF and the corresponding ECP10MDF basis for Fe. The spin–orbit coupling (SOC) corrections on the ground-state electronic energies of heavy-element compounds with open-shell electronic configurations at the metal centers, i.e., [Ce­(pyNO)4]− and [U­(pyNO)4]−/0/+ complexes, were obtained from active space self-consistent field (CASSCF) calculations using MOLPRO 2015 software. SOC was treated by a state-interacting method with SO pseudopotentials, where SO splittings were determined as a perturbation to the SR state energies and calculated from CASSCF wave functions. The diagonal matrix elements are the individual CASSCF state energies at the SR level. To reduce the computational cost to a manageable degree, the CASSCF calculations were performed on the simplified complexes based on the DFT/B3LYP optimized geometries. The idea is to reduce the size of side groups in the ligand that are bulky and electronically unimportant to less-bulky and electronically similar ones. In this work, we replace the original –C­(CH3)3 substituent at the hydroxylamine nitrogen atom in the pyNO ligand with a – CH3 substituent with a typical C–H bond lengths of 1.09 Å, and denote this simplified ligand as pyNO′. Besides, we applied the smaller 6-31G* basis sets for nonmetal atoms with the same relativistic pseudopotentials and basis sets for metal atoms as those in the DFT/B3LYP calculations. In the CASSCF calculations, the active orbitals contain all the 4f orbitals for [Ce­(pyNO′)4]− and all the 5f orbitals for [U­(pyNO′)4]−/0/+ complexes, giving CAS­(1e,7o) for [Ce­(pyNO′)4]− and [U­(pyNO′)4]+, and CAS­(2e,7o) for [U­(pyNO′)4], and CAS­(3e,7o) for [U­(pyNO′)4]−, respectively. The CASSCF calculations were performed on all the states arising from f1 configuration for [Ce­(pyNO′)4]− and U­(pyNO′)4]+, and the lowest 18 triplet states and 9 singlet states for [U­(pyNO′)4], and the lowest 21 quartet states and 16 doublet states for U­(pyNO′)4]−. The high-lying excited states of [U­(pyNO′)4]−/0 excluded in the CASSCF calculations are already 1.9 eV higher in energy than the ground states, and therefore their effects on the SOC correction of ground state energy can be neglected. The calculated SOC correction on the ground-state electronic energy is −0.127, –0.328, –0.622 and −0.635 eV for [Ce­(pyNO′)4]−, [U­(pyNO′)4]+, [U­(pyNO′)4] and [U­(pyNO′)4]−, respectively. These values are consistent with those reported results of the 4f and 5fn systems.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Details

Ground-state electronic structure calculations were performed on the [M(pyNO)4] (M = Ce, Th, U) and their oxidation and reduction products as well as Fc0 and Fc+ compounds using the hybrid functional B3LYP implemented in the Gaussian 09. All the geometries were optimized in the gas phase. Harmonic frequency calculations were performed to obtain the corresponding thermochemical corrections and to confirm that the optimized structures were stationary points on the potential energy surface. For each molecule, a subsequent single point using the implicit CPCM solvation model 51 with the Universal Force Field (UFF) radii and Solvent Excluding Surface (SES) was calculated to account for the solvation effects. A relative permittivity of 7.4257 was assumed in the solvation calculations to simulate THF as the solvent experimentally used for all the cases. We applied the 6-311G* basis sets for nonmetal atoms, Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP28MWB and the corresponding ECP28MWB-SEG basis for Ce atom, and Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP60MWB and the corresponding ECP60MWB-SEG basis for actinide atoms Th and U, and Stuttgart energy-consistent relativistic pseudopotentials ECP10MDF and the corresponding ECP10MDF basis for Fe. The spin-orbit coupling (SOC) corrections on the ground-state electronic energies of heavy-element compounds with open-shell electronic configurations at the metal centers, i.e., [Ce(pyNO)4]- and [U(pyNO)4]-/0/+ complexes, were obtained from active space self-consistent field (CASSCF) calculations using MOLPRO 2015 software. SOC was treated by a state-interacting method with SO pseudopotentials, where SO splittings were determined as a perturbation to the SR state energies and calculated from CASSCF wave functions. The diagonal matrix elements are the individual CASSCF state energies at the SR level. To reduce the computational cost to a manageable degree, the CASSCF calculations were performed on the simplified complexes based on the DFT/B3LYP optimized geometries. The idea is to reduce the size of side groups in the ligand that are bulky and electronically unimportant to less-bulky and electronically similar ones. In this work, we replace the original -C(CH3)3 substituent at the hydroxylamine nitrogen atom in the pyNO ligand with a - CH3 substituent with a typical C-H bond lengths of 1.09 Å, and denote this simplified ligand as pyNO'. Besides, we applied the smaller 6-31G* basis sets for nonmetal atoms with the same relativistic pseudopotentials and basis sets for metal atoms as those in the DFT/B3LYP calculations. In the CASSCF calculations, the active orbitals contain all the 4f orbitals for [Ce(pyNO')4]- and all the 5f orbitals for [U(pyNO')4]-/0/+ complexes, giving CAS(1e,7o) for [Ce(pyNO')4]- and [U(pyNO')4]+, and CAS(2e,7o) for [U(pyNO')4], and CAS(3e,7o) for [U(pyNO')4]-, respectively. The CASSCF calculations were performed on all the states arising from f1 configuration for [Ce(pyNO')4]- and U(pyNO')4]+, and the lowest 18 triplet states and 9 singlet states for [U(pyNO')4], and the lowest 21 quartet states and 16 doublet states for U(pyNO')4]-. The high-lying excited states of [U(pyNO')4]-/0 excluded in the CASSCF calculations are already 1.9 eV higher in energy than the ground states, and therefore their effects on the SOC correction of ground state energy can be neglected. The calculated SOC correction on the ground-state electronic energy is -0.127, -0.328, -0.622 and -0.635 eV for [Ce(pyNO')4]-, [U(pyNO')4]+, [U(pyNO')4] and [U(pyNO')4]-, respectively. These values are consistent with those reported results of the 4f and 5fn systems.

elements.content: A solution of pyNOK (191 mg, 0.932 mmol) in THF (1 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of [ThCl4(DME)4] (129 mg, 0.233 mmol) in THF (2 mL). The resulting bright yellow suspension was stirred for 10 min and the solvent removed under reduced pressure. The crude solid was extracted with dichloromethane (6 mL) and filtered through a pad of Celite to remove a small amount of colorless solid. The solution was concentrated to ca. 1 mL under reduced pressure and diluted with MeCN (5 mL). Storage at −35 °C overnight gave yellow crystals of the complex, which were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN until the washings were colorless and dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 170 mg (82%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 8.31 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H, 6-pyH), 7.03 (dd, J = 6.0, 8.7 Hz, 1H, 4-pyH), 6.67 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H, 3-pyH), 6.19 (dd, J = 5.7, 6.0 Hz, 1H, 5-pyH), 1.40 (s, 9H, C­(CH 3)3). 13C {1H} NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.19, 147.57, 134.68, 109.30, 108.49 (5 × ArC), 61.20 (C(CH3)3), 28.60 (C­(CH3)3). UV–vis-NIR: nm 371 (5800 M–1 cm–1). Anal. Calcd for C36H52N8O4Th: C, 48.43; H, 5.87; N, 12.55. Found: C, 48.58; H, 5.61; N, 12.27.

elements.content: Separate solutions of [U­(N­(SiMe3)2)3] (131 mg, 0.182 mmol) in hexane (4 mL) and pyNOH (155 mg, 0.932 mmol) in hexane (2 mL) were cooled to −35 °C. While still cold, the solution of pyNOH was carefully layered onto the solution of [U­(N­(SiMe3)2)3]. Storage of the reaction mixture overnight at −35 °C yielded the complex as a red crystalline solid. The yellow supernatant was decanted, the crystals rinsed with hexane until the washings were colorless and the complex dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 74.6 mg (46% based on U). Solutions of [U­(pyNO)4] in CH2Cl2/CHCl3 darken and turn brown in <5 min with multiple diamagnetic impurities appearing by NMR spectroscopy. The complex is sparingly soluble in THF in which it is more stable (appreciable darkening in ∼30 min). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 9.27 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, pyH), 7.70 (s, br, 1H, pyH), 5.12 (s, 9H, C­(CH 3)3), – 0.26 (s, br, 1H, pyH), – 20.43 (s, br, 1H, pyH). UV–vis-NIR: nm 380 (sh, 8500 M–1 cm–1). Anal. Calcd for C36H52N8O4U: C, 48.10; H, 5.83; N, 12.47. Found: C, 48.51; H, 5.78; N, 12.39.

A solution of pyNOK (191 mg, 0.932 mmol) in THF (1 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of [ThCl4(DME)4] (129 mg, 0.233 mmol) in THF (2 mL). The resulting bright yellow suspension was stirred for 10 min and the solvent removed under reduced pressure. The crude solid was extracted with dichloromethane (6 mL) and filtered through a pad of Celite to remove a small amount of colorless solid. The solution was concentrated to ca. 1 mL under reduced pressure and diluted with MeCN (5 mL). Storage at −35 °C overnight gave yellow crystals of the complex, which were collected by filtration, washed with MeCN until the washings were colorless and dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 170 mg (82%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 8.31 (d, J = 5.7 Hz, 1H, 6-pyH), 7.03 (dd, J = 6.0, 8.7 Hz, 1H, 4-pyH), 6.67 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 1H, 3-pyH), 6.19 (dd, J = 5.7, 6.0 Hz, 1H, 5-pyH), 1.40 (s, 9H, C­(CH 3)3). 13C {1H} NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3) δ 159.19, 147.57, 134.68, 109.30, 108.49 (5 × ArC), 61.20 (C(CH3)3), 28.60 (C­(CH3)3). UV–vis-NIR: nm 371 (5800 M–1 cm–1). Anal. Calcd for C36H52N8O4Th: C, 48.43; H, 5.87; N, 12.55. Found: C, 48.58; H, 5.61; N, 12.27.

Synthesis of [U­(pyNO)<sub>4</sub>]

Separate solutions of [U­(N­(SiMe3)2)3] (131 mg, 0.182 mmol) in hexane (4 mL) and pyNOH (155 mg, 0.932 mmol) in hexane (2 mL) were cooled to −35 °C. While still cold, the solution of pyNOH was carefully layered onto the solution of [U­(N­(SiMe3)2)3]. Storage of the reaction mixture overnight at −35 °C yielded the complex as a red crystalline solid. The yellow supernatant was decanted, the crystals rinsed with hexane until the washings were colorless and the complex dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 74.6 mg (46% based on U). Solutions of [U­(pyNO)4] in CH2Cl2/CHCl3 darken and turn brown in <5 min with multiple diamagnetic impurities appearing by NMR spectroscopy. The complex is sparingly soluble in THF in which it is more stable (appreciable darkening in ∼30 min). 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 9.27 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H, pyH), 7.70 (s, br, 1H, pyH), 5.12 (s, 9H, C­(CH 3)3), – 0.26 (s, br, 1H, pyH), – 20.43 (s, br, 1H, pyH). UV–vis-NIR: nm 380 (sh, 8500 M–1 cm–1). Anal. Calcd for C36H52N8O4U: C, 48.10; H, 5.83; N, 12.47. Found: C, 48.51; H, 5.78; N, 12.39.

Synthesis of {K­[UO<sub>2</sub>(pyNO)<sub>3</sub>]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub>

UCl4 (13.4 mg, 0.0353 mmol) was dissolved in THF (0.1 mL) and a solution of pyNOK (43.3 mg, 0.212 mmol) in MeCN (1 mL) added in one portion. The orange-red reaction mixture was left to stand overnight to yield orange crystals of the complex. The supernatant was decanted and the crystals washed sequentially with MeCN (1 mL), CH2Cl2 (1 mL) and MeCN (1 mL) and dried under reduced pressure. Yield: 17.6 mg, 62%. [UO2(pyNO)3K]n was insoluble in all common organic solvents and so NMR data was not obtained. Anal. Calcd for C27H39KN6O5U: C, 40.75; H, 4.95; N, 11.03. Found: C, 40.50; H, 4.48; N, 10.98.

Synthesis of [U­(pyNO)<sub>4</sub>]­[BAr<sub>4</sub> <sup>F</sup>]

[Fc]­[BAr4 F] (15.1 mg, 0.0144 mmol) in THF (0.2 mL) was added to solid [U­(pyNO)4] (12.9 mg, 0.0143 mmol). The dark brown solution was diluted with toluene (4 mL) and filtered through a pad of Celite. Layering this solution with hexane (4 mL) at −35 °C for 2 days gave black crystals of the complex that were collected by filtration. Yield: 20.1 mg, 79%. 1H NMR (CD2Cl2): δ 9.00 (m, br, 4H, pyH), 7.72 (s, 8H, [BArF 4]), 7.55 (s, 4H, [BArF 4]), 5.56 (d, br, J = 7.6 Hz, 4H, pyH), 4.58 (s, 36H, C­(CH 3)3), 3.06 (d, br, J = 6.1 Hz, 4H, pyH), – 2.55 (s, br, 4H, pyH). 19F­{1H} NMR (CD2Cl2): δ – 61.0 (s, [BArF 4]). UV–vis-NIR: nm 333 (7400 M–1 cm–1), 458 (3700 M–1 cm–1), 703 (sh, 2100 M–1 cm–1), 1601 (59 M–1 cm–1). Anal. Calcd for C68H64N8O4BF24U: C, 46.35; H, 3.66; N, 6.36. Found: C, 46.59; H, 3.42; N, 6.20.
